DOC.HEAD: Inland to Sell 13 Percent Stake to Nippon Steel
DOC.TEXT: Inland Steel Industries Inc. has announced plans to sell a 13 percent stake to Nippon Steel Corp. of Japan for $185 million. The proposed transaction was announced after the close of trading Monday on the New York Stock Exchange and involves the sale of 185,000 shares of a newly issued preferred stock for $1,000 a share. Chicago-based Inland will spend proceeds from the sale to buy back its common stock on the open market within a year, said company spokesman Sam Saran. Inland also agreed to place a mutually acceptable designee of Nippon Steel on its board of directors. Nippon agreed it would not acquire additional Inland shares for 10 years without Inland's approval. Nippon paid $15 million for 1 percent of Inland's common stock earlier this year, and the new transaction would raise Nippon's stake to 14 percent. The transaction will ``strengthen the company's long-term competitive position in the steel industry through an expanded strategic partnership with Nippon Steel,'' Inland Chairman Frank Luerssen said in a statement. In addition, it will provide significant benefits to stockholders, he said. Saran called the development ``another strategic move involving the close collaborative relationship between our two companies.'' He said the announcement was not an antitakeover defense. In a statement from Tokyo, Nippon Steel President Hiroshi Saito said: ``With the growth of global manufacturing enterprises, strong international relationships are increasingly important to assure our steel customers' needs in North America.'' In 1986, the two firms agreed to build a $400 million continuous cold-rolling mill in New Carlisle, Ind. The mill, which uses Nippon's technology for manufacturing sheet steel for the automotive industry, is to begin operation next year.
